awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Control Theory and Analysis of Partial Differential Equations Coupled Across a Boundary Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
In one component of this project, the investigators will study equations which mathematically describe the flow of gas as it streams within a walled cavity and interacts with a vibrating portion of the cavity's boundary. Within this mathematical framework, the investigators will attempt to determine if the gas flow and cavity wall displacement can be favorably altered or "controlled" by means of the deliberate placement of forces which act on the cavity wall. The accomplishment of this program objective could lend insight into understanding and controlling the gas flows which are associated with high-speed aircraft and natural gas pipelines. Furthermore, a mathematical model which has recently been derived to describe a structure-fluid interaction in which an elastic body is wholly immersed within a given fluid will be studied. This new mathematical model differs from previous structure-fluid models, in that numerical simulations of solutions to the new model suggest that the associated structural displacements, as well as the fluid flow field, elicit a much more quiescent behavior than previously thought. The investigators intend to mathematically verify this observed "stability" for such structure-fluid dynamics. A successful conclusion to this work could potentially enhance the understanding of cellular dynamics: such structure-fluid interaction models have been invoked to describe a nuclear body, within a cell, as it interacts with the surrounding viscous cytoplasm. Moreover, a mathematical model which describes acoustic wave flow within a structural chamber, with one of the chamber walls being flexible, will be studied. In particular, it is intended to determine if the acoustic waves in this structural model will die out as time evolves. Such a conclusion of wave stability in this mathematical setting would have implications in real-world control engineering: With a view of promoting a quiescent acoustic field within the interior of an aircraft cabin, the stability results of the project could conceivably be taken into account in aircraft fuselage design. In the course of fulfilling the project objectives, graduate students, including first generation university students and women, will receive training in the necessary qualitative analysis and numerical computation. 

The gas flow-cavity model described above consists of the 3D compressible Stokes or Navier-Stokes flow equations coupled to an elastic plate equation which describes the displacements of the flexible portion of the cavity wall. This PDE system is subjected to cavity boundary control terms. The investigators will determine the optimal regularity of solutions to such controlled (gas) flow-structure PDE models under the influence of boundary control terms of prescribed smoothness. Subsequently, they intend to solve the associated null controllability problem with respect to the appropriate space of boundary control functions. Moreover, in the aforementioned structure-fluid interaction, the structure is composed of a "thick" and "thin" layer: the thick layer is described by a 3D wave equation, while the the thin layer is described by a 2D wave equation and constitutes the boundary interface between the thick wave equation and the 3D fluid component equation. The investigators intend to establish that classical solutions of this 3D wave-2D wave-3D heat PDE system manifest at least a polynomial rate of decay, which would be in line with what has been observed numerically. In addition, the rational decay problem for the structural acoustic interaction, in which an acoustic wave equation within a bounded domain interacts with a dissipative elastic equation across a boundary interface, will be considered. Moreover, an algorithm which will confirm that the polynomial rates obtained are optimal will be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
During the course of their Project Work, the Principal Investgators (PI's) have considered  fluid-structure partial differential equation (PDE) models which constitute in part couplings of multilayered hyperbolic - parabolic dynamics. That is, the PI's have investigated PDE systems which constitute couplings of 3D elastic -- 2D elastic -- 3D Stokes/Navier Stokes systems. Each PDE component evolves within its own geometry, and so the coupling occurs across boundary interfaces. Such coupled PDE systems are used to mathematically model mammalian blood transportation systems, and account for the fact that mammalian veins and arteries are typically composed of various layers of tissues. Each tissue layer will generally manifest its own intrinsic material properties, and will moreover be separated from other layers by thin elastic laminae. In the course of their work, the PI's have established a theory of wellposedness, identified spectral properties of the associated dynamical operators, and ascertained long time behavior of solutions, for such multilayered structure-fluid PDE systems.

Moreover, during the term of the Project, the PI's, with their Graduate Students, have continued their analysis of PDE systems which are composed of three dimensional compressible gas flow equations coupled to two dimensional plate PDE's, with the coupling between the two dynamics being accomplished on a portion of the boundary of the gas flow geometry. In contrast to the fairly large body of literature on incompressible fluids, existing work on compressible fluids which interact with elastic solids is relatively limited, owing to the inherent mathematical and physical challenges induced by the presence of the extra density (pressure) variable. The PI's note that current treatments for fluid structure interaction problems involving incompressible fluids cannot be applied to the compressible flow case: in the course of meeting Project Objectives, the PI's have necessarily developed novel methodologies in order to resolve the pressure (density) component of the fluid structure interactive PDE system.

In addition, the PI's have worked to partially affirm the validity of a longstanding analyticity conjecture, concerning the qualitative behavior of a coupled partial differential equation (PDE) system, which describes a certain fluid-structure interaction (FSI). This particular FSI system comprises a Stokes (fluid) flow, evolving within a three-dimensional cavity, coupled via a boundary interface, to a two dimensional elastic equation which displaces upon a portion of the cavity boundary. In the course of this work, the PI's developed a "frequency domain" methodology by which to obtain a quantifiable measure of Gevrey (or higher) regularity for this coupled PDE system.

Furthermore, during the term of the Project work, the PI's and their Graduate Student have undertaken qualitative and quantitative studies of a certain coupled system of partial differential equations (PDE's), a PDE systems which constitutes a canonical mathematical model for various fluid-flow interactions which are seen in nature; e.g., oceanic and atmospheric interactions, and the interaction of two distinct weather fronts. By way of resolving the wellposedness of said compressible flow-incompressible fluid interaction, a particular mixed variational (or Babuska-Brezzi) formulation was constructed by the PI's and Graduate Student. The bilinear forms in this mixed variational formulation acount for the interaction between incompressible fluid and compressible Stokes flow, across the given boundary interface, and are composed in part of solution maps for uncoupled compressible Stokes flows, which correspond to given forcing terms and boundary data. Subsequently, the PI's and Graduate Student developed a companion mixed Finite Element Method (FEM) for approximating solutions of the compressible flow-incompressible fluid PDE system. This FEM includes a rigorous convergence analysis

During the course of this Project work, the PI's have also derived a mixed variational approach to resolve the wellposedness of a partial differential equation (PDE) system which mathematically models a certain poroelastic filtration--fluid flow problem. This PDE system is of current acute interest within Applied Mathematics and the Applied Sciences, generally: it consists of the Stokes flow PDE with the convoluted Biot system of equations, with the Biot PDE component comprising a Lamé system of elasticity and a parabolic pressure equation. In this course of this Project work, the PI's and Graduate Students have derived two distinct mixed variational formulations -- intrinsic to the dynamics -- by which to obtain solutions of the Bio-Stokes interaction under consideration. One of these mixed variational approaches has been subsequently invoked by the PI's for the creation of a viable mixed finite element method (FEM), by which to generate reliable numerical approximations of solutions to these Biot-Stokes PDE models. Moreover, the PI's have used the results of their mixed variational formulations to positively answer the uniqueness question concerning weak solutions of Biot-Stokes PDE systems. (This uniqueness question had been open in the literature.)


Last Modified: 09/28/2024
Modified by: George Avalos
por.por_txt_cntn:
During the course of their Project Work, the Principal Investgators (PI's) have considered fluid-structure partial differential equation (PDE) models which constitute in part couplings of multilayered hyperbolic - parabolic dynamics. That is, the PI's have investigated PDE systems which constitute couplings of 3D elastic -- 2D elastic -- 3D Stokes/Navier Stokes systems. Each PDE component evolves within its own geometry, and so the coupling occurs across boundary interfaces. Such coupled PDE systems are used to mathematically model mammalian blood transportation systems, and account for the fact that mammalian veins and arteries are typically composed of various layers of tissues. Each tissue layer will generally manifest its own intrinsic material properties, and will moreover be separated from other layers by thin elastic laminae. In the course of their work, the PI's have established a theory of wellposedness, identified spectral properties of the associated dynamical operators, and ascertained long time behavior of solutions, for such multilayered structure-fluid PDE systems.


Moreover, during the term of the Project, the PI's, with their Graduate Students, have continued their analysis of PDE systems which are composed of three dimensional compressible gas flow equations coupled to two dimensional plate PDE's, with the coupling between the two dynamics being accomplished on a portion of the boundary of the gas flow geometry. The PI's note that current treatments for fluid structure interaction problems involving incompressible fluids cannot be applied to the compressible flow case: in the course of meeting Project Objectives, the PI's have necessarily developed novel methodologies in order to resolve the pressure (density) component of the fluid structure interactive PDE system.


In addition, the PI's have worked to partially affirm the validity of a longstanding analyticity conjecture, concerning the qualitative behavior of a coupled partial differential equation (PDE) system, which describes a certain fluid-structure interaction (FSI). This particular FSI system comprises a Stokes (fluid) flow, evolving within a three-dimensional cavity, coupled via a boundary interface, to a two dimensional elastic equation which displaces upon a portion of the cavity boundary. In the course of this work, the PI's developed a "frequency domain" methodology by which to obtain a quantifiable measure of Gevrey (or higher) regularity for this coupled PDE system.

This FEM includes a rigorous convergence analysis


During the course of this Project work, the PI's have also derived a mixed variational approach to resolve the wellposedness of a partial differential equation (PDE) system which mathematically models a certain poroelastic filtration--fluid flow problem. This PDE system is of current acute interest within Applied Mathematics and the Applied Sciences, generally: it consists of the Stokes flow PDE with the convoluted Biot system of equations, with the Biot PDE component comprising a Lam system of elasticity and a parabolic pressure equation. In this course of this Project work, the PI's and Graduate Students have derived two distinct mixed variational formulations -- intrinsic to the dynamics -- by which to obtain solutions of the Bio-Stokes interaction under consideration. One of these mixed variational approaches has been subsequently invoked by the PI's for the creation ofa viable mixed finite element method (FEM), by which to generate reliable numerical approximations of solutions to these Biot-Stokes PDE models. Moreover, the PI's have used the results of their mixed variational formulations to positively answer the uniqueness question concerning weak solutions of Biot-Stokes PDE systems.
